Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
transformed_texts:
In my large urban setting, diversity reigns supreme. Residential pockets dot the landscape, interspersed with commercial zones bustling with an array of businesses, from corporate offices to independent retail outlets and eateries. This urban tapestry supports an endless variety of dining and shopping options. While global brands hold prominence, independent boutiques are increasingly trending. They line streets that are a mere stroll away from residential areas, if not for the multitude of nearby attractions. Parks within close reach host families with young children, reflecting a community that's not just diverse in origin, but also in lifestyle.

Nearby, we find significant pockets of various cultural communities, such as a vibrant LGBTQ+ enclave, a strong Orthodox Jewish presence, and a cluster of former Soviet Union refugees and immigrants. Further afield, more racial and ethnic communities thrive, often in their own distinct neighborhoods like Little Armenia or Korea town. However, distance can be deceiving; a mere 10-mile journey can stretch to over two hours due to heavy traffic. Commute on foot is rare, given the size of the city, and parking is a persistent challenge amidst new construction and an influx of residents. Despite the challenges, my city offers a mix of housing accommodations, from single-family homes to smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. This diversity is mirrored in the age demographics, with a mix of young and old. While not a close-knit neighborhood, I still cherish childhood memories of playing with neighbors, creating a sense of community that persists, even if it's not as prevalent today.

My locale is an intriguing blend of the old and the modern. The primary residences are stand-alone, although some have been reconfigured, and even attached, in a way that harks back to a bygone era. My dwelling boasts a compact front yard and a diminutive driveway to its left, reminiscent of a suburban ideal that once captivated the American spirit. This dream seems to have waned, yet my neighborhood, along with many others, persists, beckoning to us that the dream is still very much alive, though we cling to it with diminishing enthusiasm. The once vibrant optimism of the residents has waned, and the meticulous upkeep of the yards have declined. However, the driveways still bear the presence of at least one or two vehicles, while the youth continue to play as if the world beyond their immediate surroundings does not exist.

The public school, a fixture for nearly nine decades, continues to stand as a beacon of the future for today's youth, while evoking nostalgia in the older residents. The churches, though few and far between, mostly lay vacant, but the basketball courts remain bustling with activity. Each home may appear distinct, yet they share a common sense of community. A prominent supermarket, "Super A," is owned by a Yemeni family, possibly the sole Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of residents are African American, and the wide streets are a favorite playground for the children, who pause their games only briefly to let the cars pass. Most residents have deep roots in the area, and many can recount stories of a time when everyone knew everyone.

Once upon a time, a karate school was a staple, but with the decline of Hollywood's karate kid movies, the school closed its doors. Now, a pharmacy occupies the space, a symbol of the modern era's approach to problems. There's also a small movie theater that screens classic films at a discounted price, drawing the elderly despite the youth's disdain for its lack of new releases. A single expressway cuts through our town, but the nearest exit is in the neighboring town. There was a petition to bring an exit to our town, but the elders, citing potential damage to the town's charm, ultimately persuaded the city council to deny it. A new high school is under construction, and the community is debating a suitable mascot. I suggest a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin to encapsulate our unique blend of old and new.

Upon first appearance, it might seem unremarkable - just a row of apartments tucked behind a decrepit shopping center, not the kind of place one would expect to find a thriving community. However, venture past the defunct Whole Foods and the infrequently inhabited hotels, and you'll discover a vibrant neighborhood. Here, several apartment complexes stand side by side, much like Russian nesting dolls, each distinct yet connected by shared streets. The first ones you encounter have made headlines for less than savory reasons, so let's bypass those for now. Behind them, other apartment complexes offer an altogether different scene. Across the street from these complexes lies a community college's satellite campus, a sleepy haven where students sip coffee and yawn their way through lectures. Commuters often express their frustration at the campus gates, but the road soon merges with another residential area where a park and a rehabilitation center sit peacefully. The rehabilitation center boasts cheerful decor and a lazy fan that swirls the warm summer air. Children play in the park, and retirees walk their dogs along the path, casting disapproving glances at skateboarding teens and nodding politely to the girls clustered at the playground. Nearby, there's a strip mall housing a sushi spot, a swim supply store, a nail salon, and a DIY frozen yogurt shop. It's the perfect setting for a quick manicure, sushi dinner, and a pool supply run - the charm of an old strip mall. The neighborhood exudes a sense of timelessness, a slice of history in the quiet south, where change is a rare sight.

As we traversed the expansive cornfields that stretched out before us like a never-ending plain, she queried, "Where exactly are we?" I replied, anticipating her initial bewilderment at the vast, open landscape. Her upbringing in a bustling town where a grocery store was mere minutes walk from home had not prepared her for the sheer scale of the countryside. Taken aback by the prevalence of cornfields, I regaled her with tales of growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she seemed to grasp who I was and where I hailed from. Travelling down a narrow country road, one encounters a picturesque quarry, its waters shimmering in the sunlight. Beyond this, lies a small, well-kept neighborhood where homes are predominantly of brick and stucco,each sprawling across half an acre of land. Come springtime, the area blooms with an array of flowers and seasonal trees, while driveways gleam with high-end Mercedes-Benz vehicles, freshly polished under the midday sun. As we approached my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor was predictably out in the open, engaged in his daily lawn maintenance while humming a tune, much to the amusement of the neighbors. Though he's lost some of his wit with age, his past as a physician and unique history make him a beloved figure in the community. A short stroll to my home reveals a thriving goose population and a tenacious terrier, while out back, a babbling stream feeds into the quarry, accompanied by the symphony of bullfrogs and the intermittent "moo" from nearby farms. Crossing the handcrafted wooden bridge leads to an undisturbed oasis teeming with native flora and fauna, where I spent countless hours of my youth. From fort-building to 'hunting' expeditions (which often involved more running than actual hunting), there was never a shortage of activities or playmates. Winter in my small town can be harsh, but there's an unrivaled beauty in the stark transformation of the landscape. The once verdant backyard becomes a barren, snow-covered wilderness, with trees standing as skeletal silhouettes against the crisp, white canvas. Snowfall decorates the scene with a fairytale charm, leaving my sister's snow angels and snowmen scattered across the yard. Our childhood feuds were often resolved with snowballs, and we'd construct elaborate igloo-like fortresses to house our arsenal, usually comprised of branches. In this winter wonderland, we'd lose ourselves in childish games, untethered from the cares of the world.

The initial thing to grasp about Portland, Oregon is the essence of eccentricity. The unofficial town motto, emblazoned on the facade of a versatile establishment that doubles as a pizzeria, bar, music hall, and questionable entertainment venue, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a nostalgic reminder of the Portland of yesteryears, when it was less recognized and more affordable, fostering unique and creative subcultures. To others, it's an invitation - come to Portland, where people might still deem you peculiar, but in an approving manner. Despite the influx of affluent transplants from California and the relentless proliferation of condominiums, Portland remains eccentric. Eccentricity, however, does not signify complete acceptance, but rather an acceptance of the unconventional. It's a city that, like the rest of the nation, imports most of its products from China. There's an array of ways to be eccentric, to deviate from the norm, yet Portland offers ample opportunities for normalcy. Yoga, hipsters, and business professionals are all part of the cityscape. Perhaps, being weird means we simply take all of this with a grain of salt. In my neighborhood, and many others like it, you'll find vibrant houses, lush home gardens brimming with herbs and vegetables, and summertime free boxes. These are typically cardboard or plastic containers left behind by those who have no use for them. They often contain clothing and books, but anything can be found. The enchanting potential of strolling through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what makes Portland, Portland, at least in my perspective, but I am just one variety of the many weird people who inhabit this city. Other residents might not consider scavenging through sidewalk boxes, preferring activities like goat yoga (yes, yoga with real goats) or cheering on the city's soccer team. Portland is a city brimming with people who have diverse interests and passions. However, Portland also wrestles with a drug problem, which often stems from underlying mental health issues exacerbated by the prevalent rain and overcast skies. Homelessness is another significant challenge, with Portland's social services attracting many, but struggling to keep pace. The non-homeless population oscillates between compassion and animosity. In this regard, Portland is not unique, but rather a reflection of the broader societal dynamics.

The peaks, steadfast sentinels, stand constant in the north, silent witnesses to the sun's daily dance. Despite life's distractions and forgetfulness, they remain, unyielding and unperturbed by life's ebb and flow. On days when stress and anxiety peak, they beckon, offering respite and renewed vigor. I first encountered these giants when I began my undergraduate studies, and they've been my silent companions ever since. Despite the university's grandeur, the mountains hold a special place in my heart. The town boasts a blend of charm and energy, with bustling cafes and historic architecture. Yet, it's the mountains that captivate me, their majesty unrivaled. The north-south divide of urban and suburban life creates a unique atmosphere, each with its own memories, both cherished and bittersweet. The ponds, in particular, serve as a reflective sanctuary, where existential crises are weathered and life's purpose pondered. One morning, as the sun painted the sky, I realized my walk was leading me north, towards the mountains. There they stood, towering and steadfast, their peaks brushing the sky, a visual testament to resilience.

Should you be embarking on a journey to Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, you need not worry about navigating it. Public transit is abundant and a favored mode of travel in New York City. Bensonhurst, being a compact urban locale, retains the city's bustling energy. During your stay, be ready to encounter numerous Asian stores lining the streets. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurst has seen a wave of Asian inhabitants. Consequently, every block will have an Asian-owned business, predominantly supermarkets and laundromats, which locals favor for their quality, cheaper prices, and convenience. Nearby, four Asian supermarkets are within a stone's throw of each other. This reflects the area's convenience. While Bensonhurst is not solely Asian, it boasts diversity with immigrants and their children living here, with many local businesses owned by Asians. Recently, a park was refurbished, offering ten basketball courts, a soccer/baseball field, four handball courts, playgrounds, and a summer's water fountain. Diversity thrives here, with individuals of all backgrounds coexisting harmoniously. While corporate towers are scarce, co-ops and condos are common, and two-family homes are prevalent. Residents are generally friendly but noisy, with daily household disruptions, and evening safety can be a concern. Personal experiences with bullying and package theft have been rare but present. Dog waste is frequently encountered in public areas, with local residents often disregarding cleanup rules. Stay alert and keep your footwear clean!

In my locale, sidewalks are scarce, and the terrain slopes downwards, with my residence perched atop the highest point of the neighborhood's most challenging incline, affectionately dubbed the "workout hill" due to the numerous joggers who traverse it daily. The absence of sidewalks on my street compels pedestrians to tread along the road, which, while picturesque, is pockmarked and occasionally perilous to navigate. The utility wires that crisscross the area are in a state of disrepair, a consequence of the region's frequent rain and storms, which often bring down branches and debris, leaving the lines with a haphazard, patchwork appearance. Towering evergreens encircle the neighborhood, but the residents harbor a love-hate relationship with them; while they admire their beauty, they also resent their blocking the ocean view, prompting many to build high-rise homes with expansive glass facades to capture the vista.

Sunsets here are breathtaking, with the water's surface aglow and the sky ablaze in hues of orange. However, due to the persistent cloud cover, the sun's direct rays are often obscured, casting the landscape in a perpetual haze. The damp climate fosters the growth of moss, which carpets virtually every surface, including cars and railings. Once, I left my vehicle parked in the driveway for a month and returned to find it engulfed in lush, verdant moss, necessitating a labor-intensive cleaning effort. The neighborhood is predominantly inhabited by elderly residents, with many families opting for dogs as their children, with the canines frequently lounging on lawns or darting through the streets. Occasional intrusions into homes are not uncommon, as I discovered upon returning to find an uninvited canine visitor in my living room. Rabbits also roam freely, causing consternation among gardeners and delight among cats, who have successfully hunted them out of the area. Birdlife is diverse, ranging from tiny sparrows and hummingbirds to occasional visits from larger birds of prey, which are quickly chased off by the neighborhood crows.

While there are no nearby stores, a journey downhill to the waterfront reveals a few restaurants specializing in fresh seafood. The beach is limited, but the rocky shore offers hours of enjoyment, especially for stone-throwing enthusiasts. The bay is narrow, allowing a clear view of the opposite shore even on misty days.

Nestled in a classic suburban neighborhood of a small southern Tennessee town, my residence is a humble abode situated at the intersection of two major state highways. Although the increased vehicular traffic causes some disturbance, the community remains generally tranquil. With minimal turnover of residents, I have become acquainted with most of my neighbors, who primarily engage in routine activities such as yard maintenance and daily chores. In colder months, we enjoy sledding on our adjoining street. Our house, positioned at the corner, offers a clear view of the street's comings and goings, enabling us to recognize familiar vehicles. The presence of unusual autos often arouses our curiosity. Neighborhood residents engage in leisurely activities like walking their pets or cycling, and the sound of lawnmowers is a regular summer melody. Our household consists of four members: my spouse and two daughters, aged eleven and fourteen, which makes us a familiar sight in the neighborhood. We are often seen playing outdoors, even in inclement weather, and our back deck hosts occasional barbecues, filling the air with a delightful aroma.

The neighborhood is a former wooded area, boasting an abundance of trees that provide ample shade but also necessitate regular leaf raking and burning in the fall. The lack of a proper winter has extended the fall season, and our garage, positioned at the rear of the house, remains the primary point of egress. The garage also serves as my workshop for truck maintenance and other projects, making me more attuned to the neighborhood's activities when the doors are open. During holidays like Thanksgiving, Mother's Day, and Christmas, the neighborhood sees an influx of visitors from out of town, resulting in additional vehicles parked on the street. Despite the increased traffic, we enjoy living here. If it weren't for the through street, it would be the ideal setting.

Nestled in the very heart of the high desert lies my neighborhood, a landscape that is dominated by a vast expanse of earth, punctuated only by the occasional house. For those who have not experienced life here, the perpetual hue of brown is truly a unique sensation. The sight of a lawn, a rarity in this terrain, is a clear indication that the homeowner is investing considerable effort and resources into maintaining it. When I initially resided here in the 90s, the houses were spaced far apart, much like today. While there have been new additions, the overall layout remains largely unchanged. The transformation of this place into a more urban environment is an inevitable process, a trend seen in many growing cities. The people here, much like any urban area, are a mix of the welcoming and the reserved. My immediate vicinity is fortunate to be populated by a cohort of friendly, elderly residents, lending an air of warmth and familiarity to the neighborhood.

The retail scene in this town is dominated by familiar chain stores such as Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. The concept of 'upscale' shopping is not a common sight, with Whole Foods and similar establishments being hard to come by. The job market here is heavily skewed towards construction, a sector that thrives due to the city's ongoing development. I myself am a drywall and T-bar installer, a career that keeps me close to the heart of this growth. What I enjoy most about living here is the diverse array of wildlife that call this place home. The high desert's unique climate and geography have fostered a complex ecosystem, necessitating a harmony between human residents and the native species. My family, including my three children, have fully embraced this aspect of our environment, with the kids being particularly enamored with lizards and desert insects.

In terms of attractions, Victorville offers a range of experiences. For a dose of traditional family fun, the annual San Bernardino County Fair is a must-visit. For those seeking a more adventurous outing, a trip to Wrightwood for winter sports is a great option. If you're interested in the natural history and culture of the region, the Victor Valley Museum is an excellent resource. Its collection includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that chronicle the evolution of society and industry in Victorville.

In response to the request to describe my habitat, I must admit that my experience is somewhat atypical. Unlike traditional respondents who are likely homeowners, my living situation is distinctly different. My "neighborhood" is the college campus where I reside, with my fellow dormitory inhabitants comprising my community. The campus periphery also plays a role, albeit to a lesser degree. Despite this peculiarity, my abode shares some conventional neighborhood aspects.

Let's commence with the dwellings that comprise my neighborhood. Before delving into the specifics, it's prudent to identify the housing types present. Here, we have apartments, standalone houses, and dormitories. In apartments, each room accommodates 2-4 individuals, with 4-6 rooms per floor. Common buildings house about 20 residents, with two floors. Standalone homes are predominantly alumni-occupied, numbering just a few. The prevalent housing type is dormitories, accommodating 100s of residents, with most sharing rooms.

Now, let's address the inhabitants. My school's emphasis on diversity resonates in our neighborhood's makeup. Residents hail from varied cultures and age groups. Staff members typically reside in the neighborhood houses, while newer students occupy dorms, and older students reside in apartment-style accommodations. This motley crew cannot be fully captured by mere words, so let's shift focus to stores and parks.

Given the campus' self-contained nature, our neighborhood boasts numerous stores and a singular park. Dining options mirror those found elsewhere, complemented by our school's unique retail outlets. Everything needed is conveniently accessible within our boundaries. The park serves as a communal space for the diverse residents, maintained and crime-free by the community.

In the decade since my relocation, I've come to know my neighborhood well. Initially, the transition from Riverdale to Stockbridge was quite an emotional experience. I was heartbroken to leave behind my familiar surroundings and the familiarity of home, but my parents, seeking a better environment for my sister and me, made the decision to move. Our new neighborhood was perceived as more affluent, with better housing and a superior high school. As time passed, I adjusted to my new surroundings, forming friendships and, inevitably, rivalries with classmates. Among my neighbors, I've grown close to Mr. Glen and his family, including Dennis, who reside adjacent to us. They've become a sort of extended family to me. The highlight of my time here was attending Mr. Glen's wedding, a joyous event I thoroughly enjoyed, especially when I caught his wife's garter—a testament to our camaraderie. I've also explored the neighborhood with the aid of a GPS, and spent time with friends like Kason and Curtis, indulging in video games and outdoor activities. The park has been a sanctuary for me, particularly during stressful times. I often bring along items from Home Depot for balance practice, and I've even resorted to carrying my bokken wooden sword for fun. The neighborhood's sports facilities, while underutilized, remain a pleasant reminder of my past activities. My father and Mr. Graves instilled a love for tennis in both me and my best friend, and despite the rigorous training, we always found joy in our shared experiences. While I've had many enjoyable moments here, I remain excited for what the future holds in this neighborhood.

Just adjacent to the institution I'm enrolled in, my residence is situated. I find this proximity quite advantageous in that it allows for a more convenient living experience. The neighborhood predominantly comprises apartment buildings, interspersed with a handful of eateries and pubs that cater to a budget-conscious crowd. One of the establishments, recently rebranded, has seen a slight uptick in prices, yet the quality of service and beverages remains unexceptional. The inhabitants here are generally pleasant, consisting mainly of college students and those of more modest financial means, as evidenced by the affordable housing. A nearby elementary school lends the area a familial ambiance, despite the prevalence of cannabis smokers among my neighbors, prompting the management to install an air freshener unit. The buildings surrounding my abode are mostly vintage, albeit with modernized interiors. A few streets over, newer apartment complexes dot the landscape, yet their construction leaves much to be desired, as they are hastily assembled yet command high rents. A budget-friendly eatery, operating on the principle of disposable plates and microwave cuisine, resides nearby, with a gas station across the way, rumored to be an unpleasant place of employment. City funds have, however, afforded the area an upgrade, with newly paved sidewalks and landscaped medians. My building is encircled by a canopy of trees, some of which have been felled, leaving stumps as remnants. Beyond my complex lies a tree-lined avenue, with another set of apartments. I reside on 42nd Street, with a less appealing 43rd Street just a stone's throw away. The sidewalks here are in disrepair, as are many of the buildings, though the proliferation of trees may serve to obscure their decrepitude. Unfortunately, the area is not immune to crime, with incidents reported at the neighboring apartment complex. I remain content with my current dwelling, as it is within my financial reach and offers ample nearby conveniences. The university's proximity and the availability of bus stops make it a breeze to traverse to the store and downtown.

My abode is situated in a subdivision characterized by a series of duplexes arranged in a cul-de-sac. These homes are scattered in such a way that they appear as individual dwellings, save for their uniform yellow and white exterior. Nearly all neighbors are acquainted, though friendships are not universal. Evening conversations occur at the end of our driveway, accompanied by the play of neighborhood children with their toys, sidewalk art, or kites. This setting is a refreshing contrast to our increasingly mechanized world, resembling a step back in time. Our neighborhood is surrounded by fields and forests, adorned with cerulean skies and cotton-candy clouds. The sole drawback is the recent spate of tornado alerts, culminating in our first actual warning last night. I found myself huddled in my bathtub with my smallest dog, purse, and pillows. My larger dog, however, opted to stay in the living room, anxious amidst the unusual circumstances. Our neighborhood was eerily silent, save for the pelting hail. Post-storm, our street was steaming, temperature dropping from 92°F to 75°F in minutes. The hail melted upon hitting the hot pavement. As grey clouds parted, a double rainbow appeared. I snapped pictures to share with my social circle, who were equally awestruck. Quiet persisted for an hour before neighbors returned from their day's endeavors. Dinner preparations resumed, and the neighborhood returned to its cheerful rhythm. As a recent transplant from New Hampshire to North Carolina, I cherish the Southern drawl. Our two-bedroom, two-bath apartments, identical on the outside, vary in interior layout. Some are quite compact. I enjoy strolling the expansive field behind my residence to the non-swimmable pond, where I've spotted deer and heard the morning serenade of a giant bullfrog. This forty-minute retreat from Charlotte offers a sense of living in a self-contained village. A nearby farm's donkey adds to our communal charm with its evening braying. I count myself fortunate to have discovered this gem of a neighborhood.

Translocated to this residential area at the start of my eighth grade year. Initial social integration proved challenging, yet ultimately, I forged friendships with two individuals residing nearby. Both have since relocated, but my memories of those times persist. Many original residents remain, and my neighborhood is quintessentially typical of American suburban enclaves. It's populated predominantly by two-story homes, and on warm weekends, the sound of youngsters at play is a constant. Weekdays are generally tranquil, with neighbors respectful and helpful when needed. Security is reliable; I've never experienced package theft or unwanted attention. The local park, just minutes away, holds significant sentimentality. There, I've engaged in various games with neighborhood companions, including football, which resulted in a memorable yet painful nose injury. Now, I often visit the park with my younger cousin's children, their enthusiasm for playground activities evoking a sense of nostalgia. Diverse culinary options abound within a mile radius, with Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants available. Online food delivery services, like GrubHub and DoorDash, have gained popularity. Local shops cater to all needs, including an Indian-owned establishment. My neighborhood's amenities and supportive community make me truly grateful, especially when I witness the adverse experiences others face with their neighbors through social media and news reports.

My neighborhood is a picturesque hamlet nestled in the heart of South Carolina. While it blends in with the rest of the state, it holds a unique standing in the agricultural realm. The town of Johnston bears the title of the Peach Capital of the World, a moniker proudly showcased on the welcoming sign. The landscape is dominated by vast expanses of farmland, where peach orchards and cattle farms reign supreme. Houses, often two-storied with metal or gray shingled roofs, are scattered sparsely, their front fields used for agricultural purposes. The town's core hosts a solitary traffic light at an intersection, a hub for the limited businesses that call Johnston home.

Gastronomic choices in Johnston are few and far between. There's Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, and Gary's, a small, yet popular burger joint. A pizzeria once stood in its place, but it has since shut its doors. The town's pharmacy, Maxwell and Halford Drug, is well-known for its Cherry Coca-Cola. The Independent Grocers Alliance, or IGA, is the sole grocery store, though many prefer the nearby Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville for their shopping needs. Dollar General, however, is the town's most popular store, catering to everyday needs. Possibilities Furniture & More, a longstanding fixture, offers deliveries, and Clark's Cuts and Kennels provides pet grooming services nearby. Healthcare is provided by small but well-equipped doctor and veterinary practices, located away from the town's main area. Johnston Elementary School is the town's only educational establishment, with students moving to the next town for middle and high school. Recreational spaces are limited, with a 2.5-acre recreational area currently under construction. Despite its size, Johnston is a charming town, small enough to be easily traversed without notice.

Upon first learning of my current residence, I chanced upon a podcast chronicling the fates of those who have vanished. This discovery was somewhat unexpected, given the high rental prices in the vicinity, exceeding a thousand dollars monthly. Neither I nor my acquaintances were previously aware of this narrative. Perhaps it’s the universal struggle. Several of my friends find solace in sleep, grappling with the harsh realities of life's costs. We’ve adapted over the years, embracing thrift and frugality. The aroma of antique toys and worn-out clothing now holds an appeal, a true sign of adulthood. It's astonishing how the scent of age permeates, clinging to furnishings despite repeated cleaning. Here, three thrift stores are within a stone’s throw. Starting from the far end, you can visit two charity shops, a library, a rare book emporium, and a curio store. The city center bustles with activity, yet within these stores, it’s serene. Regardless of the constant influx of people and vehicles, the stores remain silent, making them ideal for leisurely browsing. Each passing year brings an increase in this urban growth. With the headquarters of one of the world's largest e-commerce and delivery companies, it continues to evolve, experiencing the growing pains of such rapid development. It's reminiscent of New York, where everyone is focused on their own pursuits, and there’s little need for interference. Here, one can exist independently, unnoticed, and still be content. Unlike the South, where concern for others is seen as a sign of care, life here is more isolated. Privacy is respected as long as one maintains their personal space. The city flows around you, much like waves on a shore. Despite living in a sprawling modernist metropolis, it’s people like my neighbors who make me feel less like a stranger and more a part of a community. We share in each other's joy and sorrow, and offer mutual support. I’m fortunate to live in such a place. I enjoy most of my neighbors, and they reciprocate my sentiments. I make efforts to keep my surroundings clean and leave them food, and they do the same for me. We exchange mail, and their presence brings me comfort, as I believe they find mine equally enjoyable. Amidst the vast, impersonal expanse of modern architecture, it’s the human connections that make my life feel less wasted.

My domicile is nestled within a community that one might describe as a bit of an assembly line neighborhood. The homeowner's association here is very prominent, as evidenced by the immaculate condition of all single-family residences. The front lawns are meticulously maintained, featuring a modest expanse of greenery, decorative stones, and compact driveways. Occasionally, one might spot a small tree or two. Each residence boasts a two-car garage, and the streets are paved with new concrete, devoid of any unsightly potholes. The majority of dwellings are single-story, though there are a few two-story homes sprinkled throughout. The mailboxes are conveniently located at the end of the street in a cluster, with residents using keys to access their specific box, and larger lockers for parcels. This uniformity is, of course, a result of the HOA's diligent oversight. My abode is on the outskirts of the nearby metropolis, blending the best of both rural and suburban living. We enjoy ample space for outdoor activities, with multiple community pools and walking trails. The neighborhood is predominantly inhabited by retirees, who maintain a watchful eye on one another, ensuring a sense of safety and camaraderie. A smattering of middle-aged and young professionals also call it home. The town, while substantial in population, maintains a small-town charm. Our neighborhood offers a plethora of amenities, including a modest shopping mall that provides ample retail options, from high-end grocers to cost-effective outlets. A short drive away, one can find a wide array of major chain stores. Overall, my neighborhood is a safe, well-cared-for community, complete with recreational facilities and easy access to commercial conveniences.

I reside in a modest community nestled in the Midwest, just on the outskirts of a bustling metropolis. My immediate locale, situated on the east end of town, is the most economically depressed area, with homes predominantly occupied or rented by low-income residents. Despite this, the aesthetic appeal is not compromised, and my neighbors are warm and welcoming, greeting me with smiles and hellos as I stroll down the street. While crime statistics are slightly higher than other parts of the town, they remain relatively low, with only a handful of serious incidents in the past decade, including shootings and a tragic homicide. Close friends nearby lost their son to a bar altercation last year. Our family has fortunately avoided direct impact, save for minor property incidents. The town grapples with the opioid crisis, with numerous lives lost to fentanyl overdoses. However, resources are available, including several rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected. The town boasts many positive aspects, including exemplary educational facilities. My child's elementary school, despite having special needs, has a positive environment where bullying is non-existent, thanks to dedicated faculty and staff. A proactive PTO organizes events to foster family engagement and educational advancement. With over 20% of the town's population living below the poverty line, the school offers free breakfast and lunch to all students, ensuring no child goes hungry. The city council has made notable improvements, but unfortunately, these enhancements are mainly concentrated in the center and west side, where commercial areas are situated. The east side, where I reside, often goes neglected, a point of contention among neighbors. Yet, I cherish living here. The people are amiable, schools are outstanding, shopping options are sufficient, and our home, though not lavish, is comfortable and sufficient. Our family has been here for over a decade, and we feel deeply connected to our town.

My locality is a rich tapestry of culture, nestled upon a rise and surrounded by architectural relics. My abode is a seven-level apartment building, situated directly across from the venerable old theatre, and a mere block down the way is a quaint arcade bar that attracts a diverse array of patrons on balmy summer evenings. During weekends in June and July, a queue often forms outside this establishment, a testament to its popularity. A few blocks further up the hill lies the nearest municipal park, notably large for its urban surroundings. Towering concrete and flights of stairs encircle the park, and in the biting cold of winter, homeless individuals set up orderly camps along the sidewalk and stairs. While snowfall is sparse, the deluges of rain during mid-winter prove challenging for maintaining warmth. Their proximity to each other and to the nearest family centre, which is a considerable distance away, allows them to better endure the harsh conditions and access amenities. My affection for this city, however, is not rooted in its historical grandeur - the soaring edifices, the architectural marvels cascading down the hills towards the sea. No, it's the people who captivate me. Hilltop, once notorious for gang activity, echoes with tales of the past, even three decades later. The community strives to keep it tidy, a testament to their resilience. They maintain a watchful eye over their neighborhood, a sentiment that has led to warnings against visiting after dark, particularly for those perceived as white. These warnings, while rooted in the past, are tinged with the bitterness of social conditioning. Perhaps it's my own skin tone or my connection to the community that makes me feel at home here. The Hilltop, despite its reputation, is not a place of darkness, but of life. I've found warmth in the night, safety in the rain, and kindness in the eyes of strangers. It is here that I feel most alive, where a jacket is offered with genuine compassion rather than malice, and a simple $5 can transform a dreary night into something brighter.

Nestled in the rural heart of America, I hail from a quaint enclave in small-town Michigan, where the landscape transitions from expansive farmland to charming tourist hubs. The absence of sprawling metropolises and recognizable big-box stores like Walmart, Target, or Applebee's is replaced with the need for a car to traverse the rural expanse. Yet, such a scenic environment, bounded by the majestic shores of Lake Michigan and Lake Charlevoix, offers breathtaking vistas and a plethora of beaches for leisurely dips. The architectural character of my neighborhood is a blend of the old and the updated, with unique homes and basements visible from the street. Aluminum siding adorns many a residence, and gardens and trampolines dot the front yards, reflecting the warmth and activity of the community. This is Middle America at its core, a place where hardworking families reside, and neighbors are on familiar terms. The lawns are meticulously maintained, and the streets echo with the laughter of children, the hum of neighbors’ conversations, and the rumble of lawnmowers. The sense of community is palpable, with people often seen walking their pets or engaging in friendly exchanges. Safety, tranquility, and a sense of belonging are paramount. Within walking distance, essential services like the county sheriff’s department, health department, and recycling center are accessible, further reinforcing the self-sufficient nature of this close-knit community. The nearby sports fields and airport add a layer of practicality and excitement, while the local ice cream parlor and park offer delightful amenities. My children can easily pedal their bicycles to the park just a few blocks away, making it an ideal setting for a family to call home.

original_texts:
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
If you are planning on visiting Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, you will not have a difficult time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular forms of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurt is a fairly urban neighborhood, so you will still feel as if you are in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see the various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurt has received an influx of Asian inhabitants. Because of this, you will see an Asian-owned store at least every block as you are walking. Most popular are supermarkets and laundromats. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents, as quality of food in the supermarkets are superb, the prices are much cheaper, and finally yet importantly, it is very convenient. Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downward, and my house sits right at the crest of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "work out hill" because so many joggers like to run up it during their daily work out. As there aren't any sidewalks at all on my street everyone walks on the road. There road is pitted in a few places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and electric wires strung up around the block at tattered looking. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often strike down the power lines and the constant repairs make them look checkered and patchwork-y. There's many tall evergreen trees all around everywhere you look. But people here hate the trees. They strive to cut down as many as possible because the trees obstruct the view of the ocean. That's why many of the houses are built so high up on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second stories that loom up one after the other to take in the view of the bay. It's gorgeous around sunset when the water seems to get lit up from below and the sky turns orange. It's cloudy more often than not, though, so you end up seeing most of the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked out in my driveway for a month and when I went out to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. Took me three hours to scrap it all off. There aren't that many children around where I live, though there's a school only a few blocks away. Most of the people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting out in people's lawns or racing down the street after each other. If you leave a door or window open you risk having them sneak into your house. I found one once in my living room and had to shoo it back out the front door. Rabbits run wild around the area. Some of them are good sized, and the gardeners hate them because the dig up the roots of plants and burrow into people's lawns. My cats love them though, and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also get the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle sometimes swoops by until the neighborhood crows chase it off. There aren't any stores around, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront there's a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There isn't much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to hurl into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can see the opposite shoreline clearly even through the mist on most days.
I live in a typical suburb area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a connecting street between two state highways, so we get a bit more traffic on the street than I'd like, but other than that, it's a quiet neighborhood. There's not too many folks that move in and out, so I've grown used to most of the people that live in the neighborhood. People busy themselves with yard work and other daily chores for the most part. In the winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live in a house at the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day long and are familiar with the cars that people drive around here. Whenever we see a strange vehicle, we tend to take note of it. Some of the neighbors go walking for exercise or just to walk their dogs. Kids play on their bikes and all that you would expect from that. We are at home a lot since we work from our house. There are four of us, Myself and my Wife, and two Daughters ages eleven and fourteen. So, I'd say that everyone else is used to us coming and going as well. We get outside and play, sometimes even in the rain. Once in a while we grill outside on our back deck and it's always a pleasant smell from the barbecue and all. It seems that there's always someone cutting grass around here and you can hear a lawn mower nearly every day from March through about October, when the grass finally stops growing. We have a lot of trees in our neighborhood as it was originally a wooded area, so there's lots of shade, but there's always a lot of leaves in the Fall as well. So, that means raking and burning the leaves on a yearly basis. I like the smell of burning leaves too, so that's always a nice sign that Fall has arrived. Lately, we've not been having much Winter to speak of, so it just feels like a long Fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we seldom use the front door of our house unless someone knocks on the door, which is rare. I like to work in the garage on my truck or other projects from time to time and when I have the garage doors open, it feels like I'm more tuned into the neighborhood. On holidays it is pretty quiet around here. Thanksgiving sees some of the neighborhood families visiting with people from out of town and there are extra cars parked everywhere during that time of year. It's the same at other holidays like Mother's day and Christmas. All in all, I like living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.
My neighborhood is in the smack middle of the high desert, where there is dirt, dirt and more dirt. Unless someone has actually experienced living here, they probably donâ€™t really understand the feeling of always seeing brown , and when you do see a lawn, you know that person is spending a fortune on lawn care. When I first lived here in the 90s, houses were spread out far and wide. Now it is pretty much the same way by there are a lot of new additions. Honestly this place looks more and more like a city everyday, but supposed most places are changing the same way. Most of the time the people are very friendly, but just like any city you have your good parts and bad. In my neighborhood I'm surrounded by friendly old people iI guess it's a nicer neighborhood. The stores in this place are pretty much the store who have chains, like food for less and smart and final. If you want uscale you have to travel I never really see any whole foods or stores of that nature. The jobs that are most prominent in my city I would say not based on any official demographics, is construction. I think this is on account of this city is still not very developed, there is still a lot of wide open spaces to build. That kind of scares me, I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and I'm not keen on going back. Speaking of construction this was the field my full time job is located in, i am a drywall and T-bar instalator. What I like about my home is the different animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, not the least of which is the stark beauty of the desert itself. High desert climate and topography have created challenging ecosystems which need protecting and which are home to different types of wildlife. Human residents of the high desert should take the time to learn about the non-human residents who share this environment in order to co-exist safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted very well to the wildlife. I have three children and they are all obsessed with lizards and dessert bugs, as I am writing this now they are outside trying to catch different specimens. As far as attractions goes we have some. Additionally, Victorville is a good place for families to experience the desert. It can generate a different experience. If you can, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. The fair will enrich your visit with the right mix of activities and fun the Victorville way. Pop by the nearby Wrightwood to see the snow covered mountains and take some winter sports lessons to finish out your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of the development of society and industry of Victorville.
When asked to describe my neighborhood, I'm sure that my answer is somewhat unique. While others who respond to this are most likely homeowners with their own individual lives, my situation is a tad bit different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus that I stay on, and the people that live in my dormitory to be my community. I also consider the surrounding campus to be my neighborhood, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares some commonalities with the more conventional ideas about a neighborhood. Just like any conventional neighborhood, the neighborhood I stay in has houses, people, stores and parks. Let us begin by discussing the "houses" that comprise my neighborhood. Before I begin to explore the houses in my neighborhood, it would be best to clarify the types of house that can be found in my neighborhood. There are three types of housing in my immediate vicinity, the apartments, the actual houses, and the dormitory houses. First, In the apartments, there are usually between 2-4 people in any given room, and there are about 4-6 rooms on each floor. The most common building type can house about 2 floors, so on average, there are 20 or so people living in each building. Second, are the actual houses that are available for anyone with an affiliation to the school to rent. Typically these are 2-4 bedroom setups that usually have alumni living in them. However, there are only a handful of these types of houses spread throughout the neighborhood, as they are less efficient. Finally, there are the typical dorm rooms which house 100's of students. In these, you have two people sharing a room with some exception, and it is the most common type of housing in my neighborhood. With housing covered we are ready to move on to the people. My school prides itself on diversity and this is reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. There are people from all cultures and ages that live in my neighborhood. Most of the professional staff live in the houses that are placed in the neighborhood, whereas the newer students stay in the dormitory style housing and the older students stay in the apartment-style housing. The people in this neighborhood can't be done justice by simply talking about them, so it would be best to simply move on to the stores and parks in my neighborhood. Since my school really is it's own self-contained neighborhood, it has a plethora of stores and a single park. The stores are a mix of dining options that would be found in any other neighborhood, and the schools own unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. As such, anything that is needed can be found within my neighborhood's boundaries! Additionally, the park in my neighborhood is a playground for all the diverse people in my neighborhood, it is kept clean and free of crime by all the members of my neighborhood!
Well, considering that I’ve been here for about 10 years, I guess I can share what I know. First off, I was pretty sad when I first came to my neighborhood. I came from Riverdale to Stockbridge, and I’m not going to lie, I cried, because I missed them and I loved them.. but my mom and dad wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we moved to a better location for housing, a better high school, everything was considered “not ghetto” when we moved to our new neighborhood. Throughout the years, I got used to it, and made some new friends, and some new enemies too in school. I never really truly got to know my neighbors throughout the years, except Mr. Glen and his children, as well as Dennis for a bit, both being right next to us. They have been enjoyable people that I almost can consider as family in some ways, and I truly do appreciate them. I remember when me, mom, dad, and my sister went to Mr. Glen’s wedding (They got re-married) It was really fun and enjoyable to say the least, and something I’m looking forward to someday, as I build my wealth and give my future wife the life of a Queen. When Mr. Glen’s wife, Ms. Veda, took off the white little strap on her leg and threw it, I caught it! Sadly I didn’t catch the flowers! We all danced the night away, and I really enjoyed having a good time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I haven’t seen her since though. I hope she’s moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood itself is like a maze, although now I have a GPS, so I can take more time to explore it. I’ve only went so far, and that is when I’ve hung out with my friends Kason and Curtis. We all used to play video games alot, and just enjoy life to the fullest as much as we could. Sometimes I would go to the park and enjoy nature, which soothes my soul. It gives me a sense of calmness and peace these days. I’ll also bring some sticks that I bought from home depot and just practice my balance, And bring my bokken wooden sword if I can,. I have fun enjoying what I love to do. There’s also a basketball and tennis court, although I haven’t played tennis or basketball in a long time, It’s still nice to have in case I ever want to pick it back up and give it another go. My dad grew me and my best friend up on Tennis with Mr. Graves, and we’d always have a great time.. They worked us hard! But we always had fun. I guess there’s a lot of times I’ve had fun in this neighborhood, and there’s plenty of stories, but these are what really stuck out to me, and I believe that the best, is yet to come!
My neighborhood is nearby to the college that I attend, and for that I quite enjoy living there. There are mostly apartment buildings, but a few restaurants and bars that are fun to go to and aren't terribly expensive to go to. One of the bars was just renamed, and that one is more expensive to go to but it isn't really the worst quality of service or drinks there. Most of the people are nice. They are either college kids or they are lower income, since the apartment housing isn't very expensive. There's a lot of children nearby since there is an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don’t know my neighbors, but I don’t really want to. They smoke a lot of weed and so the management of my building put an air freshener unit right across from their door, which my boyfriend and I found very funny. It’s almost insulting. The buildings that are around me are usually pretty old looking but might have renovated interiors. Down the street a bit there are brand new apartments, but I don’t like them because I know the construction done on them wasn’t particularly good. They’re cheaply built but the rent is expensive, which I think is such a scam but because they’re near campus, the management of those buildings can get away with it. There is a really cheap restaurant about five minutes from where I live that serves food only on paper plates and most of what they make is microwaved. Then across from that is a gas station, which I’ve heard isn’t a very good place to work. But thanks to some money from the city, the road was redone last summer so that there’s a nice big sidewalk, lots of grass on the medians and sides of the roads, and now the area is a little nicer. But the apartment building I live in is shrouded in tress. They cut a few of them down, so there are a few stumps, but there are a lot more trees where I live than down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and then another set of apartments. I live on 42nd street, but right behind is 43rd street and that one isn’t as nice. The sidewalks are really bad and falling apart, and most of the buildings on it look shabby. There are a lot of trees on this street, but that is probably to hide what the buildings look like. Most of the crime in my area has happened at an apartment complex on that street, but then again, I can’t blame just them. There are apartments across the street from me that also have a lot of crime and a rather transient population. But I think I like where I live.
